results.title: Viskingar och rop = Cries and whispers
results.creator_credit: Cinematograph for Svenska Filminstitutet, Svenska filminstitutet and Ingmar Bergman
results.brief_description:
Two sisters, Maria and Karin, tend their sister, Agnes, dying of cancer, in the family mansion. Over the course of the film the three sisters and the family maid, Anna, examine their past, lamenting dark and tumultuous moments. Maria is a self-centred, vain, exquisite beauty, with a shallow perspective; Karin, bitter and frigid has a history of self-mutilation and contemplates suicide; Agnes, in immense pain, is comforted by Anna the fatalistic family retainer. Bergman artfully explores the inner life of the women, detailing the history of their connectedness yet isolation from each other. With flashbacks and minimal dialogue Bergman lays out the emotional landscape of this family’s fragile bonds that strain under the imminent death of one. Clocks are a repeated motif for the passage of time, and a reminder of the women’s mortality; sound and colour play an important part in the narrative with red (wine, walls, curtains) representing the soul’s interior. Set in the late 1800s, ‘Cries and Whispers’ is an intense, disturbing and powerful family drama about repression, spirituality, sexual passion, hatred and death.

Credits: Producer, director, writer, Ingmar Bergman ; photography, Sven Nykvist ; editing, Siv Lundgren.
Cast: Harriet Andersson, Kari Sylwan, Ingrid Thulin, Liv Ullmann, Erland Josephson, Henning Moritzen.

results.title: Sommaren med Monika = Summer with Monika
results.creator_credit: Allan Ekelund, Svensk Filmindustri and Ingmar Bergman
results.brief_description:
A chance meeting between Harry, an errand boy, and Monika, a wild and reckless young woman from the poorer quarter of Stockholm (a strikingly assured performance by Andersson), leads to an affair and an escape from the city for a holiday on the nearby islands. The summer idyll is abruptly shattered when Monika finds that she is pregnant. While Harry accepts the responsibilities of parenthood, Monika is less willing. The light and open space of the islands is contrasted with the dark claustrophobia of the city. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Allan Ekelund ; director, Ingmar Bergman ; writers, Ingmar Bergman, Per Anders Fogelstrom ; photography, Gunnar Fischer ; music, Erik Nordgren ; editors, Tage Holmberg, Gosta Lewin.
Cast: Harriet Andersson, Lars Ekborg.

results.title: Deep in my heart
results.creator_credit: Stanley Donen, Roger Edens and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: This film ‘biopic’ portrays the life of composer Sigmund Romberg, whose scores included “The Desert Song” and “Maytime”. While Broadway swings to the jazzy beat of ragtime, Romberg chooses to play the beautiful waltzes of his native country. When Romberg is convinced by the owner of the Cafe Vienna to try his hand at ragtime he writes a hit song in no time at all. Romberg writes one smash hit after another and eventually creates a hit show that takes Broadway by storm. Based on the book by Elliot Arnold. Stars Jose Ferrer, Merle Oberon, Helen Traubel, Walter Pidgeon with special guest appearances by Ann Miller, Rosemary Clooney, Cyd Charisse, Gene Kelly and Howard Keel.

results.title: Solaris
results.brief_description:
A distant planet fathoms the fears and memories buried in its observer’s minds and externalises these into living beings. As a result an astronaut relives a doomed relationship with his lost wife. In the novel by Polish writer Stanislaw Lem, Tarkovsky found the elements of obsession and repetition he needed for access to his own life - science fiction as grandiloquent autobiographical text. (Adapted from a note by Patrick Strick, NFT, London). Also available on VHS.

Credits: Director, Andrei Tarkovsky ; script, Friedrich Gorenstein, Andrei Tarkovsky ; photography, Vadim Yusov ; music, Eduard Artemyev ; production designer, Mikhail Romadin ; editor, Ludmila Feganova.
Cast: Natalya Bondarchuk, Donatas Banionis, Yuri Yarvet, Nikolai Grinko, Anatoly Solonitsyn.
Note: Based on the novel by Stanislaw Lem.

results.title: Agonia = Agony
results.creator_credit: Elem Klimov, Semion Kutikov and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
In the final days of the Romanov regime (1613-1917), the ‘mad monk’ Rasputin wields power at the court. He is portrayed as a man completely out of touch with the people and political reality, immersed in sexual decadence and the lascivious manipulation of others. The relationship of Rasputin, the Czar and the Empress are explored in this historical drama, with the latter two falling under Rasputin’s spell. Klimov takes a docu-drama approach mixing colour re-enactments of historical events with simulated black and white newsreel footage. This film was completed in 1975 but due to its sympathetic portrayal of Czar Nicholas II, was not released until 1981

Credits: Producer, Semion Kutikov ; director, Elem Klimov ; writer, Semyon Lungin, Ilya Nusinov ; photography, Leonid Kalashnikov ; music, Alfred Shnitke.
Cast: Velta Linei, Alisa Freindlikh, Anatoly Romashin, Alexey Petrenko, A. Romantsov, S. Muchenikov.

results.title: The Phantom of the opera
results.creator_credit: Carl Laemmle, Universal Pictures, Rupert Julian and Edward Sedgwick
results.brief_description:
In his most famous role as Erik the Phantom, Chaney demonstrated his genius for mime, and his ability to bring humanity to the most deformed of creatures. Produced by Universal, the film was shot in 1923 and shelved for nearly two years, and was subjected to intensive studio tinkering. It was both the stepping off point for Chaney’s run as a superstar at M.G.M. and the prototype for the horror film cycle at Universal in the 1930s. The story concerns Erik, a much-feared fiend who haunts the Paris Opera House. Lurking around the damp, dank passages deep in the cellars of the theater, he secretly coaches understudy Christine Daae to be an opera star. Through a startling sequence of terrors, including sending a giant chandelier crashing down on the opera patrons, the chandelier crashing down on the opera patrons, the Phantom forces the lead soprano to withdraw from the opera, permitting Christine to step in. Luring Christine into his subterranean lair below the opera house, the Phantom confesses his love. Alternative versions also available on 16mm film and VHS.

Credits: Producer, Carl Laemmle ; directors, Rupert Julian, Edward Sedgwick ; writers, Raymond Shrock, Elliot Clawson ; photography, Charles Van Enger, Virgil Miller, Milton Bridenbecker ; art director, Dan Hall.
Cast: Lon Chaney, Mary Philbin, Norman Kerry, Gibson Gowland.

results.title: The Birth of a nation
results.creator_credit: Frank Woods, D.W. Griffith and D W Griffith Productions
results.brief_description:
This epic Civil War drama portrays life in the South during and after the Civil War. The film derives its emotional power from its moving constantly from the large drama to intimate human stories, in particular the war’s effects on a Northern family (the Stonemans) and its Southern counterpart (the Camerons). It is one of the most influential films in the history of the cinema and, because of its racism, one of the most controversial. Also available on 35mm and VHS. Other versions also available on 16mm.

Credits: Producer, director, D.W. Griffith ; writers, D.W. Griffith, Frank E. Woods ; photography, G.W. Bitzer.
Cast: Lillian Gish, Mae Marsh, Henry Walthall, Ralph Lewis.

results.title: Melancholia
results.creator_credit: Colin MacCabe, BFI and Andi Engel
results.brief_description:
An existential political thriller that grapples with the legacy of post-1968 European political activism. A successful but angst ridden German art critic, established in London, is contacted by a student friend from the 1960s to assassinate a Chilean military torturer. Approaching a comfortable middle age, he is unsettled by the disruption which forces him to confront his political convictions and choose between the activism of his youth or the complacency and security of his present life. Filmed on location in London and Hamburg.

Credits: Producer, Colin McCabe ; director, Andi Engel ; writer, Andi Engel, Lewis Rodia ; phototography, Denis Crossan ; editing, Christopher Roth ; music, Simon Fisher Turner.
Cast: Jeroen Krabbe, Susannah York, Ulrich Wildgruber, Kate Hardie.

results.title: War requiem
results.creator_credit: James MacKay, Anglo International Films, British Broadcasting Corporation and Derek Jarman
results.brief_description:
Cinematic interpretation of Benjamin Britten’s 1961 masterly religious/poetic choral oratorio, combining the Latin Mass with several poems by the British war poet Wilfred Owen. Owen was killed on the battlefield a week before the armistice that ended WWI. Jarman merges dramatic sequences, paintings, collages and documentary footage from the wars of the 20th century to evoke the tragedy of war and the untimely death of youth. The film has been interpreted as a metaphor on the war against AIDS. A film without dialogue, featuring Olivier in his final film role.

Credits: James Mackay ; director, writer, Derek Jarman ; photography, Richard Greatrex ; editing, Rick Elgood.
Cast: Laurence Olivier, Tilda Swinton, Nathaniel Parker, Owen Teale, Nigel Terry.
